page.title: 02Ecology
page.content: The area being largely agricultural land is home to much wildlife. Evidence of the existence of fox, rabbit, deer, squirrel and hare is abundant. The River Blackwater ensures the existence of fish such as tench and perch and water creatures such as rat. The birds observed include crow, blackbird, robin, cuckoo, pigeon and migrating birds such as swallow, swift and martin. The climate of Essex is fairly dry with cold east winds. Reservoirs to conserve rainwater for irrigation of crops also attract birdlife. The footpaths marked on the O.S. map are recognisable but often overgrown. Pollution from the trunk road to the north is minimal but the regular spraying of crops is of concern to conservationists. Trees in the area include oak, willow, beech, sycamore, poplar, ash and fir.
